children.text: The recording begins with us bumping the shotgun microphone, which is pointed outward toward a large, flat landscape.
As we orient the microphone around the landscape, dry grass in the desert crunches under our feet.

annotation.text: A dead porcupine lies in the center of the photograph, just beyond the white line seperating the road from the shoulder. Unseen on the right side of the photograph is a natural gas and oil processing plant, alongside drilling rigs.

children.text: Beyond the paved lines of the road, where the once-were animals find a place to slowly bleed out: this at least tells us that there is existing life to be potentially killed. In the Permian Basin, there is no roadkill, there is no present deadness. The absence of deadness on the side of the road isn’t a sign of life, it’s a sign of undeadness. Unoccupied street shoulders mean that everything is too dead for deadness.
The only sound that can be heard is the beginning of a gust of wind coming through. Otherwise, the silence continues until the end of the recording.
